docs.lead_paragraph: Obesity makes ovarian cancer more deadly, a new study reports. Obese women with advanced ovarian cancer have a shorter time to recurrence and a shorter overall survival time than women of ideal weight -- and not because obese people often have other medical problems. Obesity itself, the researchers suggest, is the problem. Ovarian cancer is fairly common. ''About one in 60 American women will develop ovarian cancer,'' said Dr. Andrew J. Li, the senior author of the study, a faculty physician at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center and an assistant professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of California, Los Angeles. Each year, about 20,000 new cases are diagnosed and about 15,000 women die of the disease, according to the American Cancer Society.

headline.main: Obesity Is Found to Make Ovarian Cancer Deadlier

docs.abstract: Dr Andrew J Li, Cedars-Sinai Medical Center physician, leads study on impact of obesity on ovarian cancer; research, which is published in journal Cancer, finds that obesity can make ovarian cancer more deadly; suggests that fat tissue may encourage tumor growth or make tumors less sensitive to chemotherapy; says being obese does not increase risk of developing ovarian cancer; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Acne is affected by changes in season. THE FACTS -- Does acne change with the weather? Many dermatologists say it is generally thought to flare up in the winter and improve in the summer.
docs.abstract: Research shows that in many cases acne can be affected by seasons; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: THE CLAIM --  Acne is affected by changes in season.    THE FACTS -- Does acne change with the weather? Many dermatologists say it is generally thought to flare up in the winter and improve in the summer.

docs.lead_paragraph: In Mary V. Relling's office in St. Jude Children's Research Hospital sits a small ceramic statue of St. Jude Thaddeus, the patron saint of impossible causes. Dr. Relling, the head of the department of pharmaceutical sciences at St. Jude, has a fondness for impossible causes.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH -- Mary V. Relling; Saving Lives With Tailor-Made Medication

docs.abstract: Mary V Relling, St Jude Children's Research Hospital, Memphis, pharmaceutical sciences department head, discusses practice of pharmacogenetics, clinical discipline in which doctors tailor drugs for patients based on genetic information; describes why pharmaceutical companies are not supportive of plan to tailor drugs for patients; works primarily with children's illness; photo (M)

headline.main: Medical Errors? Patients May Be the Last to Know

docs.abstract: Recent study led by Dr Thomas H Gallagher of University of Washington finds that doctors are more likely to tell patients about medical errors, if error is apparent; research, which is published in Archives of Internal Medicine, says that doctors often avoid saying mistakes were made when speaking with patient (M)
